intro: Loxanthocereus acanthurus subsp. pullatus, commonly known as the Mexican night-blooming cactus, is a flowering plant native to Mexico. It belongs to the Cactaceae family and is characterized by its spiny stems and nocturnal blooming habits. The plant produces large, showy flowers that typically open at night, attracting nocturnal pollinators such as bats and moths. Its adaptations to arid environments include thick, fleshy stems for water storage and reduced leaves to minimize water loss. The subspecies pullatus is distinguished by its specific geographic distribution and unique floral characteristics.
